text: I don't know about you guys but I can
use a pretty a few weeks ago I went down
to the pages Club where the owner Audrey
Saunders showed me how to make a classic
martini I'm gonna show you guys how to
do it too
we're gonna start with ice I'm gonna use
cold draft ice which is what they use at
the Pago pub they come in about one and
a quarter inch cubes you can get those
silicone molds that create pretty much
the same thing I'm gonna put this ice
cube in the palm of my hand and take a
bar spoon there really any spoon will
work and crack it some are easier to
crack than others I'm kind of go ahead
and fill this like two-thirds of the way
that way when I add the spirits it's
gonna get nice and cold all right that's
all right now for the most important
part the booze with any recipe I want to
taste my raw ingredients before I mix
them together just to make sure they're
gonna work Godfrey Theatre and Roy Lee
Pat I pasted them together before I know
they're great so that's what I'm going
to use this is a pretty standard [ __ ]
it's 3/4 ounces on one side and an ounce
and a half on the other so first bit
oily 3/4 ounce pour detention until you
get that little convex edge okay right
in the glass now the dinner so 4 ounces
same thing we're gonna pour detention
that's that's 3
I'm just gonna pour another ounce for
now for the stirring kind of my favorite
part the important thing is to not hold
the glass it's gonna warm up the drink
and what we want to happen is the ice to
melt slowly and just dilute the alcohol
a little bit that's gonna take the edge
off I'm gonna do this cool finger dance
and hold the edge with my thumb then put
my pinky on the board for stability so
holding from the top you kind of twirl
it like spaghetti and I'm gonna start 50
times 50 is the magic number for perfect
dilution you'll see the ice kind of
loosen up as you stir it that's how you
know you're ready I'm gonna pour this
into a Nick and Nora glass I've got one
chilling in the fridge it's so pretty
looks like a tulip super classy way to
serve a martini this is a Hawthorne
strainer you've seen it in cocktail sets
it's gonna catch any of the stray ice
chips as I pour and into the glass if
you've got a little bit extra can serve
it in a little sidecar on ice okay last
thing the twist usually we are used to
taking twist off with a peeler or
something but we want to create some
tension in the citrus so I've got a
little paring knife and I'm just gonna
take off an inch or so and a little bit
of pith is okay that's gonna make it
stiff enough to squeeze from like four
or five inches away just give it a
squeeze and you'll see in good light the
oils kind of danced across the top of
the martini then rim the glass some of
those oils right on the nose and then
just float that twist right on top now
that with the class to martinis Thursday

that's cooked like a pro
